questions.question: What is electric current?
questions.answer: Electric current is the flow of electric charges through a conductor. In metals, electrons act as charge carriers. Current flows when there is potential difference.

questions.question: What is electrostatic potential?
questions.answer: Electrostatic potential is the electric level of a point that decides the direction of charge flow. Charges move from higher to lower potential.

questions.question: Define potential difference.
questions.answer: Potential difference is the difference in electric potential between two points. It causes electric current to flow in a circuit.

questions.question: Why does bulb glow only when cell is connected?
questions.answer: Without a cell there is no potential difference. The cell provides energy to move electrons, so current flows and bulb glows.

questions.question: In which direction do electrons flow?
questions.answer: Electrons flow from the negative terminal to the positive terminal of the cell through the external circuit.

questions.question: What is conventional current direction?
questions.answer: Conventional current flows from positive terminal to negative terminal, opposite to electron flow.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of current?
questions.answer: The SI unit of electric current is Ampere (A). One ampere means one coulomb of charge flowing per second.

questions.question: What is an electric cell?
questions.answer: An electric cell is a device that maintains constant potential difference between its terminals and supplies electric current.

questions.question: What is the function of electrolyte in a cell?
questions.answer: Electrolyte contains positive and negative ions. These ions take part in chemical reactions to produce electric current.

questions.question: Name the terminals of a dry cell.
questions.answer: Graphite rod acts as positive terminal and zinc cover acts as negative terminal in a dry cell.

questions.question: Why are dry cells convenient to use?
questions.answer: Dry cells can be used in any position and do not spill liquid. They are portable and have longer shelf life.

questions.question: Why do dry cells give small current?
questions.answer: Chemical reaction in dry cell is slow due to wet paste electrolyte, so large current cannot be obtained.

questions.question: What is a battery?
questions.answer: A battery is a group of cells connected together to obtain higher potential difference and current.

questions.question: Why are cells connected in series?
questions.answer: Series connection increases total potential difference of battery, which increases current in the circuit.

questions.question: What is the voltage of three 1.5 V cells in series?
questions.answer: In series connection, voltages add. So total voltage will be 4.5 V.

questions.question: What is a lead-acid cell?
questions.answer: It is a rechargeable cell with lead and lead dioxide electrodes dipped in dilute sulphuric acid.

questions.question: Where are lead-acid cells used?
questions.answer: They are used in cars, trucks, motorcycles and UPS systems because they can supply large current.

questions.question: What are lithium-ion cells used for?
questions.answer: They are used in mobiles, laptops and modern gadgets. They store more energy and are rechargeable.

questions.question: What is an electric circuit?
questions.answer: It is a closed path made of cell, wires, switch and load through which current can flow.

questions.question: Why does bulb stop glowing when key is open?
questions.answer: Opening the key breaks the circuit. No current flows, so bulb does not glow.

questions.question: What is magnetic effect of electric current?
questions.answer: When current flows through a wire, it produces magnetic field around it, affecting nearby magnets.

questions.question: Who discovered magnetic effect of current?
questions.answer: Hans Christian Oersted first observed that current carrying wire deflects magnetic needle.

questions.question: What is an electromagnet?
questions.answer: It is a temporary magnet formed when current flows through a coil wound on iron core.

questions.question: Why does electromagnet lose magnetism?
questions.answer: When current stops flowing, magnetic field disappears and iron core loses magnetism.

questions.question: Give one use of electromagnet.
questions.answer: Electromagnets are used in electric bells, cranes and scientific instruments.

questions.question: What is main part of electric bell?
questions.answer: Electromagnet, iron strip, contact screw and striker are main parts of electric bell.

questions.question: Why does striker hit gong repeatedly?
questions.answer: Circuit makes and breaks repeatedly due to contact screw, causing continuous attraction of iron strip.

questions.question: Why does contact break in electric bell?
questions.answer: When iron strip is attracted, it moves away from screw, breaking circuit and stopping current.

questions.question: Why does bell ring continuously?
questions.answer: Make-and-break of circuit happens rapidly, so striker keeps hitting gong again and again.

questions.question: Why is soft iron used in electromagnets?
questions.answer: Soft iron magnetizes easily and loses magnetism quickly, which is needed in electric bell.

questions.question: What happens when magnetic needle is near current carrying wire?
questions.answer: Magnetic needle deflects showing that magnetic field is produced around the wire.

questions.question: Why does magnetic field disappear when current stops?
questions.answer: Magnetic field is produced only due to moving charges, so it disappears when current stops.

questions.question: Why is battery called source of energy?
questions.answer: Battery converts chemical energy into electrical energy to move charges in circuit.

questions.question: Why is zinc used as negative terminal?
questions.answer: Zinc loses electrons easily and acts as source of electrons in the circuit.

questions.question: Why is manganese dioxide used in dry cell?
questions.answer: It helps in chemical reaction and prevents buildup of hydrogen gas at positive terminal.

questions.question: Why is graphite rod used as positive terminal?
questions.answer: Graphite is good conductor and does not react chemically, so it safely collects electrons.

questions.question: Why are rechargeable cells useful?
questions.answer: They can be charged again after discharge, reducing cost and environmental waste.

questions.question: Why are solar cells important?
questions.answer: They produce electricity using sunlight and do not cause pollution.

questions.question: Why is cell symbol used in circuit diagram?
questions.answer: Symbols make circuit diagrams simple, clear and easy to understand.

questions.question: What happens if bulb is fused?
questions.answer: Filament breaks and circuit becomes open, so no current flows.

questions.question: Why is copper used for connecting wires?
questions.answer: Copper is good conductor and allows electrons to flow easily with less resistance.

questions.question: Why does thicker wire carry more current?
questions.answer: Thicker wire has less resistance, allowing more electrons to flow.

questions.question: What happens if battery is connected wrongly?
questions.answer: Current direction reverses but device may still work; polarity matters in some appliances.

questions.question: Why is switch important in circuit?
questions.answer: Switch controls flow of current by making or breaking the circuit.

questions.question: Why does current not flow in open circuit?
questions.answer: Path is incomplete so electrons cannot move continuously through circuit.

questions.question: Why is insulation needed on wires?
questions.answer: Insulation prevents electric shock and avoids short circuit between wires.

questions.question: What is load in electric circuit?
questions.answer: Load is device like bulb or motor that uses electrical energy to do work.

questions.question: Why is potential difference necessary?
questions.answer: Without potential difference, electrons will not move and current will not flow.

questions.question: What causes chemical reaction in cell?
questions.answer: Contact between electrolyte and electrodes causes chemical reaction that produces charges.

questions.question: Why is bell circuit designed to break automatically?
questions.answer: Automatic breaking allows repeated attraction of iron strip, producing continuous ringing.

questions.question: Why is iron core used in electromagnet?
questions.answer: Iron increases strength of magnetic field produced by coil when current flows.

questions.question: Why does iron strip return to original position?
questions.answer: When magnetism stops, attraction disappears and strip returns due to its elasticity.

questions.question: What will happen if battery is weak?
questions.answer: Less current will flow and devices like bulb may glow dim or not work.

questions.question: Why are dry cells used in torches?
questions.answer: They are small, portable and suitable for low current devices.

questions.question: Why does current not flow in broken wire?
questions.answer: Circuit becomes open and continuous path for electrons is not available.

questions.question: Why is chemical energy converted to electrical energy?
questions.answer: Chemical reactions separate charges and create potential difference, causing current.

questions.question: Why are UPS batteries rechargeable?
questions.answer: They use lead-acid cells which can reverse chemical reaction during charging.

questions.question: Why are Ni-Cd cells used in gadgets?
questions.answer: They are small, rechargeable and give steady voltage for portable devices.

questions.question: Why does magnetic needle return after current stops?
questions.answer: When magnetic field disappears, needle aligns again with Earthâ€™s magnetic field.

questions.question: Why is electromagnet stronger than bar magnet?
questions.answer: Strength can be increased by increasing current and number of coil turns.

questions.question: What will happen if iron core is removed?
questions.answer: Magnetic field will become weak because coil alone produces weaker magnetism.

questions.question: Why does bell not ring when wire is loose?
questions.answer: Loose wire breaks circuit, stopping current flow through electromagnet.

questions.question: Why is zinc outer case in dry cell?
questions.answer: It acts as container and negative electrode at the same time.

questions.question: Why is battery needed in home inverter?
questions.answer: It stores electrical energy to supply power during power failure.

questions.question: Why does battery voltage decrease with use?
questions.answer: Chemicals get consumed during reactions, reducing ability to produce potential difference.

questions.question: Why is carbon rod not consumed in dry cell?
questions.answer: Carbon does not participate in chemical reaction, it only collects electrons.

questions.question: Why are batteries harmful to environment?
questions.answer: They contain harmful chemicals which pollute soil and water if not disposed properly.

questions.question: Why should used cells be recycled?
questions.answer: Recycling prevents pollution and recovers useful materials from batteries.

questions.question: Why is current called flow of charges?
questions.answer: Because movement of electrons or ions through conductor forms electric current.

questions.question: Why is electric bell not using permanent magnet?
questions.answer: Permanent magnet cannot switch ON and OFF magnetism, which is needed for ringing.

questions.question: Why is bell silent when power supply is off?
questions.answer: Without current, electromagnet does not work and striker cannot move.

questions.question: Why is wire coated with plastic?
questions.answer: Plastic prevents electric shock and short circuit.

questions.question: Why does current increase when voltage increases?
questions.answer: Higher potential difference pushes more electrons through conductor per second.

questions.question: Why is iron attracted to electromagnet?
questions.answer: Iron becomes magnetized in magnetic field and gets attracted to coil.

questions.question: Why is cell symbol long and short line?
questions.answer: Long line shows positive terminal and short line shows negative terminal.

questions.question: Why are batteries connected in series in torch?
questions.answer: To increase voltage so bulb can glow brighter.

questions.question: Why is electrical energy easy to use?
questions.answer: It can be converted easily into light, heat, sound and motion.

questions.question: Why does electric shock occur?
questions.answer: When current passes through body tissues, it disturbs nerve signals causing shock.

questions.question: Why are safety fuses important?
questions.answer: They break circuit when excess current flows, preventing damage and fire.

questions.question: Why are bulbs connected in parallel at home?
questions.answer: Each appliance gets same voltage and works independently.

questions.question: Why does cell get exhausted?
questions.answer: Chemical substances are used up, so reaction stops producing electricity.

questions.question: Why is current small in human brain?
questions.answer: Only micro current flows in nerves for signals, not for power supply.

questions.question: Why is electromagnet used in cranes?
questions.answer: It can lift heavy iron objects and release them by switching off current.

questions.question: Why does current not flow in plastic?
questions.answer: Plastic has no free electrons, so it does not conduct electricity.

questions.question: Why is metal used in circuit path?
questions.answer: Metals have free electrons which can move easily and conduct current.

questions.question: Why does current stop when cell is removed?
questions.answer: Potential difference disappears and electrons stop moving.

questions.question: Why is bell striker made of iron?
questions.answer: Iron is attracted by electromagnet and can move quickly.

questions.question: Why are batteries not kept near fire?
questions.answer: Heat can cause leakage or explosion of chemicals inside battery.

questions.question: Why is current dangerous at high voltage?
questions.answer: High voltage pushes large current through body, causing severe damage.

questions.question: Why is switch placed in live wire?
questions.answer: It completely cuts off supply when switched off, ensuring safety.

questions.question: Why does wire heat up when current flows?
questions.answer: Resistance in wire converts electrical energy into heat energy.

questions.question: Why are thick wires used for heavy appliances?
questions.answer: They can carry large current without overheating.

questions.question: Why is bulb filament thin?
questions.answer: Thin filament has high resistance and glows when heated by current.

questions.question: Why does magnetism increase with more coil turns?
questions.answer: More turns increase magnetic field strength around iron core.

questions.question: Why is chemical reaction essential in cells?
questions.answer: It produces separation of charges creating electrical energy.

questions.question: Why do devices stop when battery is dead?
questions.answer: No chemical reaction remains to supply electric current.

questions.question: Why is bell circuit self-operating?
questions.answer: Automatic make and break of contact keeps ringing continuous.

questions.question: Why is current invisible?
questions.answer: Electrons are very small and cannot be seen with naked eyes.

questions.question: Why does current flow only in closed path?
questions.answer: Continuous loop is needed for electrons to return to source.

questions.question: Give conclusion of current electricity and magnetism chapter.
questions.answer: Electric current is flow of charges due to potential difference and produces magnetic effects useful in devices like bells and motors.
